natural problem: Triangle $ABC$ has three different integer side lengths. Side $AC$ is the longest side and side $AB$ is the shortest side. If the perimeter of $ABC$ is 384 units, what is the greatest possible difference $AC - AB$?
natural solution: For this problem we must remember the Triangle Inequality Theorem that states that the shortest side must be longer than the positive difference of the other two sides.

We will try to make a long skinny triangle with side $AB$ as short as possible. First we try making $AB$ equal to 1 unit. Then the other two sides must have a difference less than 1 unit in order to form a triangle.

The closest we can come with integers is 191 and 192, but that won't work. The shorter sides will lay flat on the longest side and will fail to make a triangle. Next we try making AB equal to 2 units. If the  other two sides were 191 each, we would have a triangle, but all three sides would not have different lengths.

If the other two sides were 190 and 192, we wouldn't have a triangle. Finally, we try making $AB$ equal to 3 units. Then the other two sides could be 190 and 191 units, and we can now form a  triangle.
The greatest possible difference is therefore $191 - 3 = \boxed{188\text{ units}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes AB AC BC :: nat
assumes h0 : "AB < BC \<and> BC < AC"
and h1 : "AB + BC + AC = 384"
shows  "AC - AB \<le> 188"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Triangle $ABC$ has three different integer side lengths. Side $AC$ is the longest side and side $AB$ is the shortest side. If the perimeter of $ABC$ is 384 units, what is the greatest possible difference $AC - AB$? The final Answer is 188\text{ units}
 ### Proof
 For this problem we must remember the Triangle Inequality Theorem that states that the shortest side must be longer than the positive difference of the other two sides.
 We will try to make a long skinny triangle with side $AB$ as short as possible. First we try making $AB$ equal to 1 unit. Then the other two sides must have a difference less than 1 unit in order to form a triangle.
 The closest we can come with integers is 191 and 192, but that won't work. The shorter sides will lay flat on the longest side and will fail to make a triangle. Next we try making AB equal to 2 units. If the  other two sides were 191 each, we would have a triangle, but all three sides would not have different lengths.
 If the other two sides were 190 and 192, we wouldn't have a triangle. Finally, we try making $AB$ equal to 3 units. Then the other two sides could be 190 and 191 units, and we can now form a  triangle.
 The greatest possible difference is therefore $191 - 3 = \boxed{188\text{ units}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes AB AC BC :: nat
assumes h0 : "AB < BC \<and> BC < AC"
and h1 : "AB + BC + AC = 384"
shows  "AC - AB \<le> 188"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Consider three lengths AB, AC, and BC such that AB is less than BC and BC is less than AC. If the sum of these three lengths is 384, find the maximum possible difference between the lengths AC and AB. The result should be less than or equal to 188.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes AC AB BC :: nat
assumes h0 : "AC > BC"
and h1 : "BC > AB"
and h2 : "AC + AB + BC = 384"
shows  "AC - AB \<le> 188"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Triangle $ABC$ has three different integer side lengths. Side $AC$ is the longest side and side $AB$ is the shortest side. If the perimeter of $ABC$ is 384 units, what is the greatest possible difference $AC - AB$? The final Answer is 188\text{ units}
 ### Proof
 For this problem we must remember the Triangle Inequality Theorem that states that the shortest side must be longer than the positive difference of the other two sides.
 We will try to make a long skinny triangle with side $AB$ as short as possible. First we try making $AB$ equal to 1 unit. Then the other two sides must have a difference less than 1 unit in order to form a triangle.
 The closest we can come with integers is 191 and 192, but that won't work. The shorter sides will lay flat on the longest side and will fail to make a triangle. Next we try making AB equal to 2 units. If the  other two sides were 191 each, we would have a triangle, but all three sides would not have different lengths.
 If the other two sides were 190 and 192, we wouldn't have a triangle. Finally, we try making $AB$ equal to 3 units. Then the other two sides could be 190 and 191 units, and we can now form a  triangle.
 The greatest possible difference is therefore $191 - 3 = \boxed{188\text{ units}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes AC AB BC :: nat
assumes h0 : "AC > BC"
and h1 : "BC > AB"
and h2 : "AC + AB + BC = 384"
shows  "AC - AB \<le> 188"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: int
assumes h0 : "a > 0 \<and> b > 0 \<and> c > 0"
and h1 : "a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c"
and h2 : "a + b + c = 384"
and h3 : "a > c \<and> c > b"
shows  "a - b = 188"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Triangle $ABC$ has three different integer side lengths. Side $AC$ is the longest side and side $AB$ is the shortest side. If the perimeter of $ABC$ is 384 units, what is the greatest possible difference $AC - AB$? The final Answer is 188\text{ units}

 The closest we can come with integers is 191 and 192, but that won't work. The shorter sides will lay flat on the longest side and will fail to make a triangle. Next we try making AB equal to 2 units. If the  other two sides were 191 each, we would have a triangle, but all three sides would not have different lengths.
 If the other two sides were 190 and 192, we wouldn't have a triangle. Finally, we try making $AB$ equal to 3 units. Then the other two sides could be 190 and 191 units, and we can now form a  triangle.
 The greatest possible difference is therefore $191 - 3 = \boxed{188\text{ units}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: int
assumes h0 : "a > 0 \<and> b > 0 \<and> c > 0"
and h1 : "a \<noteq> b \<and> a \<noteq> c \<and> b \<noteq> c"
and h2 : "a + b + c = 384"
and h3 : "a > c \<and> c > b"
shows  "a - b = 188"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Three positive integers $a$, $b$, and $c$ are such that they are not equal and their sum is $384$. If $a$ is the greatest and $b$ is the smallest among them, find the difference between $a$ and $b$. The final answer is $188$.

theorem
fixes A B C :: int

shows  "A - B = 188"

 Triangle $ABC$ has three different integer side lengths. Side $AC$ is the longest side and side $AB$ is the shortest side. If the perimeter of $ABC$ is 384 units, what is the greatest possible difference $AC - AB$? The final Answer is 188\text{ units}
 ### Proof
 For this problem we must remember the Triangle Inequality Theorem that states that the shortest side must be longer than the positive difference of the other two sides.
 We will try to make a long skinny triangle with side $AB$ as short as possible. First we try making $AB$ equal to 1 unit. Then the other two sides must have a difference less than 1 unit in order to form a triangle.

 The greatest possible difference is therefore $191 - 3 = \boxed{188\text{ units}}$.

theorem
fixes A B C :: int
assumes h0 : "A > B"
and h1 : "A > C"
and h2 : "B < C"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes AC AB BC :: real
assumes h0 : "AC > AB"
and h1 : "AC > BC"
and h2 : "AB < BC"
and h3 : "AC + AB + BC = 384"
shows  "AC - AB \<le> 188"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Triangle $ABC$ has three different integer side lengths. Side $AC$ is the longest side and side $AB$ is the shortest side. If the perimeter of $ABC$ is 384 units, what is the greatest possible difference $AC - AB$? The final Answer is 188\text{ units}
 ### Proof
 For this problem we must remember the Triangle Inequality Theorem that states that the shortest side must be longer than the positive difference of the other two sides.
 We will try to make a long skinny triangle with side $AB$ as short as possible. First we try making $AB$ equal to 1 unit. Then the other two sides must have a difference less than 1 unit in order to form a triangle.

Next we try making AB equal to 2 units. If the  other two sides were 191 each, we would have a triangle, but all three sides would not have different lengths.
 If the other two sides were 190 and 192, we wouldn't have a triangle. Finally, we try making $AB$ equal to 3 units. Then the other two sides could be 190 and 191 units, and we can now form a  triangle.
 The greatest possible difference is therefore $191 - 3 = \boxed{188\text{ units}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes AC AB BC :: real
